conclusion: Use properties of ideal gas and relationship between internal energy and temperature.
Internal energy of ideal gas is U = aT.
Temperature at state A is T_0.
Internal energy at state A is U_A = aT_0.
Pressure at state A is p_0 and volume is V_0.
Pressure at state C is 0.6p_0 and volume is 0.5V_0.
Use ideal gas law PV = nRT.
Express temperatures at states A and C in terms of pressures and volumes.
At state A: P_A V_A = n R T_A.
At state C: P_C V_C = n R T_C.
Since T_A = T_0, P_A V_A = n R T_0.
For state C, P_C V_C = 0.3p_0 V_0.
From ideal gas law, 0.3p_0 V_0 = n R T_C.
P_A V_A = n R T_0, and since P_A = p_0 and V_A = V_0, p_0 V_0 = n R T_0.
Therefore, T_C = 0.3 T_0.
Process from A to B is a horizontal line on the pV diagram, volume is constant.
Volume at state B is V_0.
Pressure at state B is 0.6p_0.
Using ideal gas law, find temperature at state B.
At state A: P_A V_A = n R T_A and T_A = T_0, so p_0 V_0 = n R T_0.
At state B: P_B V_B = n R T_B and V_B = V_0, so 0.6p_0 V_0 = n R T_B.
Substitute n R = p_0 V_0 / T_0 into equation for state B: 0.6p_0 V_0 = (p_0 V_0 / T_0) T_B.
